[SEC] 1. Introduction.[SUBSEC] 1.1 Purpose: The Archives Space System (AS) defines functional, technical, and security requirements for managing and preserving archival records.
[SEC] 1. Introduction.[SUBSEC] 1.2 Scope: AS supports record creation, metadata management, access control, rights handling, and long-term preservation.

[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.1 System Interfaces: AS integrates with LDAP, EAD, MARCXML, APIs, and external repositories for metadata exchange.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.2 User Interfaces: AS provides web-based workflows for archival description and authentication.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.3 Hardware Interfaces: AS operates on cloud or on-premises servers.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.4 Software Interfaces: AS supports REST APIs for data exchange and integration with preservation tools.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.5 Communications Interfa: AS ensures secure HTTPS for metadata retrieval.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.6 Memory Constraints: AS optimizes hierarchical data storage for archival records.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.7 Operations: AS ensures 24/7 availability with automated backups.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.8 Site Adaptation Requir: AS supports localized metadata and configurable policies.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.9 Interfaces with Servic: AS links to repositories, indexing tools, and aggregators.

[SEC] 1. Introduction.[SUBSEC] 1.4 Product Functions: AS enables record creation, metadata handling, and rights management.
[SEC] 1. Introduction.[SUBSEC] 1.5 User Characteristics: AS serves archivists, researchers, and administrators.
[SEC] 1. Introduction.[SUBSEC] 1.6 Limitations: AS depends on third-party metadata aggregators and repositories.
[SEC] 1. Introduction.[SUBSEC] 1.7 Assumptions and Dependencie: AS requires compliance with archival and data protection standards.

[SUBSEC] 2.1 External Interfaces.REQ-INTF-001: The system shall integrate with LDAP for authentication and access control.
[SUBSEC] 2.1 External Interfaces.REQ-INTF-002: The system shall support EAD, MARCXML import/export, and REST APIs for interoperability (REQ-DSGN-001).

[SUBSEC] 2.2 Functions.REQ-FUNC-002: The system shall allow metadata import, record editing, and role-based access (REQ-INTF-002).
[SUBSEC] 2.2 Functions.REQ-FUNC-003: The system shall mint DOIs and manage version history (REQ-DB-002).

[SUBSEC] 2.3 Usability Requirements.REQ-USAB-001: The system shall provide an intuitive, web-based interface with accessibility support (REQ-DSGN-002).

[SUBSEC] 2.4 Performance Requirements.REQ-PERF-001: The system shall process metadata uploads within 5 seconds.
[SUBSEC] 2.4 Performance Requirements.REQ-PERF-002: The system shall support 5,000 users without degradation (REQ-ATTR-002).

[SUBSEC] 2.5 Logical Database Requiremen.REQ-DB-001: The system shall store metadata in an indexed relational database.
[SUBSEC] 2.5 Logical Database Requiremen.REQ-DB-002: The system shall manage record versions and track changes.

[SUBSEC] 2.6 Design Constraints.REQ-DSGN-001: The system shall comply with archival metadata standards (e.g., EAD).
[SUBSEC] 2.6 Design Constraints.REQ-DSGN-002: The system shall encrypt all data in transit and at rest.

[SUBSEC] 2.7 Standards Compliance.REQ-COMP-001: The system shall adhere to ISO 14721 for digital preservation.

[SUBSEC] 2.8 Software System Attributes.REQ-ATTR-001: The system shall provide role-based access control.

[SEC] 3. Verification: Tests for record creation, metadata validation, security compliance, and performance benchmarks.
[SEC] 4. Supporting Information: Metadata schemas, system architecture, and security protocols.
[SEC] 5. References: ISO 14721, LDAP, EAD, and MARCXML standards.
